bibl.title: Letter from Archibald Malloch to Philip Showalter Hench, January 2, 1942

div1.p: Malloch writes that he will make negative photostats of the yellow fever manuscript for Hench.

div1.head: Letter from Archibald Malloch to Philip Showalter Hench, January 2, 1942
div1.opener:
THE NEW YORK ACADEMY OF MEDICINE
2 EAST 103RD STREET
NEW YORK
2 January, 1942
Library
Telephone ATwater 9-4700
Cable: “Nyacadmed”
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I enclose a photostat order blank for
your signature. Meanwhile we are going
ahead with your order for negative photostats
of the yellow fever manuscript. You should
have it before the seventh of the month. I
am very much afraid that the photostat will
not be much clearer than the microfilm, as
the manuscript is dim and hard to reproduce.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Archibald Malloch, M.D.
Librarian GLA
P.S. This Library is open on Saturday from 9:00 A.M.
to 10:00 P.M., but not at all on Sunday. I am not
yet certain about my movements on Saturday the 10th,
but if I am here in the morning (from 9:30 to 12:00)
I shall be very glad to see you. We are packing some
of our valuable things, but I hope we will not have
reached the yellow fever note-book by that time.
[P.T.O.]
Ac
NO
I am afraid you did not answer my question about the
second microfilm. Was it any better than the first? And,
were the left-hand pages of it also much poorer than the
right-hand pages? You did not say in the wire whether
you had received my letter of 26 December. Again let
me say that I do not believe that you will find that
the photostats will be satisfactory either.
